topic.title: The Basic Structure of the Title Statement (//fileDesc/titleStmt)

body.p: The Title Statement (<titleStmt>) of the File Description is used for specifying title (s) (in the <title> element) and author (s) (in the <author> element) of the respective work, as well as the publisher of the DTA full text edition (in the <editor> element). In addition, possible further responsibilities for individual instances of the text in the digitization process are clarified (in the element <respStmt>).
body.codeblock: <titleStmt> <title type="main">[main title]</title> <title type="sub">[subtitle]</title> <!-- to be used several times if applicable --> <title type="volume" n="[DTA volume number]">[volume designation]</title> <!-- if applicable --> <title type="part" n="[number of the part of a multi-part dependent publication]"> [title of the part of a multi-part dependent publication] </title> <!-- if applicable --> <author>[author]</author> <!-- to be used several times if applicable --> <editor corresp="#[XML-ID of the Publication Statement]"> [publisher of the present text edition] </editor> <!-- to be used several times if applicable --> <respStmt>[responsibility in the case of external contributors]</respStmt> </titleStmt>
body.note: The <titleStmt> of the File Description contains the author (s) of the work as well as the publishers of this DTA text edition. Possible publishers/translators of the underlying source are only listed in the Source Description, even if the work cannot be assigned to an author. See chap. Information on the Underlying Source.
body.p: See below for the substructuring of the elements <author> and <editor> as well as for the substructuring of the element <respStmt>.
